titleInfo.title: Perform to Belong New Affective in-Betweens for Transnational Minorities

mods:mods.abstract: This thesis traces transnational performances of race, ethnicity, nationality, political belonging, and sexuality—as well as issues of labor and fetishization invoked by some of these identities—as a way to think about satiating or satisfying certain desires of belonging. Through a robust investigation of the affective in-between, this thesis theorizes how intersectional minoritarian identities might be performed successfully in order to thrive in a nation-state dominated by majoritarian identities. Using Anne Anlin Cheng's theorization of racialized grief as a starting point, Chapter One addresses the position of the Asian immigrant in the United States, socioeconomically and culturally on their own as well as politically in relation to the white American and the Black American. Chapter Two tracks the transnational and non-linear scopes of learning to perform queerness, brownness, and political belonging, emphasizing the conflicting, perpetuating, and renewing components that comprise performances of identities, and prompting a theorization of the affective in-between as "nowhere nation." According to this theory, intersectional and transnational identities might coexist together against the societal default, but the performance of one identity must necessarily fail in order for the performance of another identity to succeed. Chapter Three focuses on the performative potential of affect, leading to the theorization of another affective in-between, "saudesh," which encompasses the complexities of embodying an event as intergenerational and transnational affect. Chapter Four provides a series of examples detailing how the minoritarian migrant works and fails to gain equitable access to the capitalist Western institution, thus addressing the complication of labor in understanding the in-between. Desire remains the driving force at every step of the investigation.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the School of Theatre in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts.
affect, identities, minoritarian, performance, South Asian, transnational
Aaron C. Thomas, Professor Directing Thesis; Irvin Manuel Gonzalez, Committee Member; Chari Arespacochaga, Committee Member.
